entry.title: Debugging VirtualBox Issues on Fedora 33
entry.content:
Installing Virtualbox should fairly be as easy as below

  1. Download the tar files
  2. Install the tarfiles(either dpkg/yum/rpm/dnf)
  3. Install the required dependencies

That is how I imagine it. Might be as simple as it looks or maybe not, not when you hit this kinds of issues. I’ll be describing what I have encountered while installing VirtualBox on the newly install Fedora 33.

Fedora 33 has just been released almost 3-4 weeks ago. And as of today Nov 27, there hasn’t been any official rpm file on Oracle’s virtualbox download page.

I have been doing all this stuff for a long time and I have never encountered such an issue as what I had just now.

What are the normal steps that I used to install VirtualBoxVM

  1. Download the official rpm file on VirtualBox’s website
  2. rpm -ivh VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64.rpm
  3. Wait for a dependency issues to come up.
  4. Pray that all kernel modules gets compiled.
  5. That’s it.

This considering is just to install the basic rpm files excluded the guest additions.

What are this issues?

  1. rpm -ivh VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64.rpm had a dependency issue that I have not encountered before
root@localhost Downloads]# rpm -ivh VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64.rpm
warning: VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64.rpm: Header V4 DSA/SHA1 Signature, key ID 98ab5139: NOKEY
error: Failed dependencies:
        python(abi) = 3.8 is needed by VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64

How did I resolved this issue?

  • Take note: this may not be the best solution, it is a dirty hack and it is not supported by vendors. use it at your own risk.

I do not take all this credits too below are the notable sites that I’ve used for reference purpose

  1. Install rpmrebuild(dnf install rpmrebuild)

  2. Do a rebuild by using below

a.

rpmrebuild --change-spec-preamble='sed -e "s/6.1.16_140961_fedora32/6.1.16_140961_fedora33/"' --change-spec-requires='sed -e "s/python(abi) = 3.8/python(abi) >= 3.8/"' --package VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64.rpm

b.

[root@localhost Downloads]# rpmrebuild --change-spec-preamble='sed -e "s/6.1.16_140961_fedora32/6.1.16_140961_fedora33/"' --change-spec-requires='sed -e "s/python(abi) = 3.8/python(abi) >= 3.8/"' --package VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora32-1.x86_64.rpm

Documenting this outputs incase you get a different output.

(GenRpmQf) remove tag line ENHANCESFLAGS
(GenRpmQf) remove tag line ENHANCESNAME
(GenRpmQf) remove tag line ENHANCESVERSION
(GenRpmQf) remove tag line SUGGESTSFLAGS
(GenRpmQf) remove tag line SUGGESTSNAME
(GenRpmQf) remove tag line SUGGESTSVERSION

result: /root/rpmbuild/RPMS/x86_64/VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64.rpm

c. You’ll find the created new rpm file in /root/rpmbuild/RPMS/x86_64/VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64.rpm

d. Also you need to take note of installing all the dependencies

dnf install binutils gcc make patch libgomp glibc-headers glibc-devel kernel-headers kernel-devel dkms qt5-qtx11extras libxkbcommon

e. Install the new rpm file

dnf install /root/rpmbuild/RPMS/x86_64/VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64.rpm

Output:

[root@localhost Downloads]# dnf install /root/rpmbuild/RPMS/x86_64/VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64.rpm
Last metadata expiration check: 0:03:46 ago on Wed 25 Nov 2020 10:01:26 AM AEDT.
Dependencies resolved.
========================================================================================================================
 Package                     Architecture        Version                                Repository                 Size
========================================================================================================================
Installing:
 VirtualBox-6.1              x86_64              6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1               @commandline               88 M

Transaction Summary
========================================================================================================================
Install  1 Package

Total size: 88 M
Installed size: 197 M
Is this ok [y/N]: y
Downloading Packages:
Running transaction check
Transaction check succeeded.
Running transaction test
Transaction test succeeded.
Running transaction
  Preparing        :                                                                                                1/1
  Running scriptlet: VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64                                                 1/1
  Installing       : VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64                                                 1/1
  Running scriptlet: VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64                                                 1/1

Creating group 'vboxusers'. VM users must be member of that group!

This system is currently not set up to build kernel modules.
Please install the Linux kernel "header" files matching the current kernel
for adding new hardware support to the system.
The distribution packages containing the headers are probably:
    kernel-devel kernel-devel-5.9.8-200.fc33.x86_64
This system is currently not set up to build kernel modules.
Please install the Linux kernel "header" files matching the current kernel
for adding new hardware support to the system.
The distribution packages containing the headers are probably:
    kernel-devel kernel-devel-5.9.8-200.fc33.x86_64

There were problems setting up VirtualBox.  To re-start the set-up process, run
  /sbin/vboxconfig
as root.  If your system is using EFI Secure Boot you may need to sign the
kernel modules (vboxdrv, vboxnetflt, vboxnetadp, vboxpci) before you can load
them. Please see your Linux system's documentation for more information.

  Verifying        : VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64                                                 1/1

Installed:
  VirtualBox-6.1-6.1.16_140961_fedora33-1.x86_64

Complete!

f. I hit another error! , Virtualbox has been installed but virtualbox service is not starting up, Solution is make sure your kernel headers and devels version matches your current kernel use. I was not able to document this part

g. Also another issue, my current kernel is not allowing an unasigned kernel modules to be compile.

There were problems setting up VirtualBox.  To re-start the set-up process, run
  /sbin/vboxconfig
as root.  If your system is using EFI Secure Boot you may need to sign the
kernel modules (vboxdrv, vboxnetflt, vboxnetadp, vboxpci) before you can load
them. Please see your Linux system's documentation for more information.

Here is what I did on how I sign my kernel, there are 2 solutions

  1. Enable Disable UEFI on your BIOS
  2. Using mokutil to sign your new certificate

This site below gives you an understanding about as to why we need to remake a new hardware key for secure boot mode

https://docs.oracle.com/en/operating-systems/oracle-linux/tutorial-mokutils-uefi/#background

Generating the certificate

a. Install mokutils

dnf install mokutil

b. Create a folder where you will be storing the RSA key

sudo -i
mkdir /root/signing-modules
cd /root/signing-modules
openssl req -new -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout MOK.priv -outform DER -out MOK.der -nodes -days 36500 -subj "/CN=VirtualBox/"
chmod 600 MOK.priv

c. Run the command below, you need to put a password and you will require it later once you perform a reboot

sudo mokutil –import MOK.der

d. Reboot your workstation, a blue screen will appear and choose this Enroll MOK –> Continue , then key in your password

e. There is a good script that was available in the site to sign your vbox kernel modules

vi ./sign_vbox, then add below and run.

#!/bin/bash

for modfile in $(dirname $(modinfo -n vboxdrv))/*.ko; do
  echo "Signing $modfile"
  /usr/src/kernels/$(uname -r)/scripts/sign-file sha256 \
                                /root/signed-modules/MOK.priv \
                                /root/signed-modules/MOK.der "$modfile"
done

f. modprobe vboxdrv

entry.title: Creating a Containerized Jekyll Environment
entry.content:
I used to create and maintan blogs on wordpress(I still have my old one hosted on wordpress https://kreatures.wordpress.com/, I have migrated this to my previous site hosted on a webhosting company however due to cost of maintaining my webhosting and domain it got terminated) and have not maintain it for a long time, there is nothing wrong with using wordpress. It is easy, convinient and very manageable, If you have a development based wordpress setup, i’m pretty sure that you are familiar that wordpress relies on a few services such as Database(mysql/mariadb etc), php and more. While it is not really hard to setup all this since you got LAMP/WAMP and just need a few tweaking of adding Php components and more. In the end it is up to you on what choose based on your comfortability.

I started exploring Jekyll and hosted it in github, if you are reading this. This is hosted in github

Jekyll provides a static based site blog in short there is no database but just static files(html files)

Enough with my blogging history

First thing that I thought of putting on my blog is to create a maintainable Development environment, Jekyll is built on ruby so if you wanted to use jekyll you need to install Ruby first and then install Jekyll via gem and that’s it.

There are other ways of having a Jekyll environment apart from installing all the components on your local workstation.

  1. Use a VM(KVM or VirtualBox). Eventhough this can be maintain and reuse, i’d still go for the 2nd option.
  2. Use container via docker, you need docker service running on your workstation.

Here is a short HowTo’s on creating a dockerized jekyll environment without a need to install

  1. I am using an existing Docker images from

https://github.com/envygeeks/jekyll-docker

There are 3 available images that are available and i’ll just go with the default image

jekyll/jekyll: Default image.
jekyll/minimal: Very minimal image.
jekyll/builder: Includes tools.
  1. Make sure docker service is running first. I always forget to bring up my docker service, I better put it on systemd. For the sake knowing how to automatically bring it up

You can run

systemctl status docker

[rbaisas@localhost ~]$ systemctl status docker
● docker.service - Docker Application Container Engine
     Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/docker.service; disabled; vendor preset: disabled)
     Active: active (running) ...

  1. Make sure to download your jekyll blog(you can go to https://jekyllrb.com/docs/themes/) or you can simply just run “jekyll new " and this creates a default theme Jekyll blog

  2. Now go the site folder and run

docker run --rm -it   --volume="$PWD:/srv/jekyll"   --volume="$PWD/vendor/bundle:/usr/local/bundle"  -p 4000:4000 jekyll/jekyll:3.8   jekyll serve

[root@localhost ~]# docker ps -a
CONTAINER ID   IMAGE               COMMAND                  CREATED          STATUS          PORTS                               NAMES
71c59acafa2a   jekyll/jekyll:3.8   "/usr/jekyll/bin/ent…"   28 seconds ago   Up 27 seconds   0.0.0.0:4000->4000/tcp, 35729/tcp   awesome_faraday

To break it down on what this parameters are:

a. –rm - Parameter removes the components once the container terminates b. –volume=”$PWD:/srv/jekyll - This maps your current blog folder to /srv/jekyll folder on the image. c. –volume=”$PWD/vendor/bundle:/usr/local/bundle” - It will create a cache on the local folder in order to properly use bundle d. -p 4000:4000 - Will be the port number to use e. jekyll/jekyll:3.8 - This is the jekyll that we will be using f. jekyll serve - Will be the command to trigger to start serving the blog under port 3000 g. it - This is the docker paramter that allocates a pseudo TTY and will prompt an open STDIN input

docker run –rm -it
–volume=”$PWD:/srv/jekyll”
–volume=”$PWD/vendor/bundle:/usr/local/bundle”
jekyll/jekyll:3.8
jekyll build
